channel.title: AI News Aggregator - Full Text
channel.description: Recent AI News with Full Content

item.title: [NEW] The countdown’s almost over: 2 days until TechCrunch All Stage 2025 kicks off in Boston (AI News & Artificial Intelligence | TechCrunch)
item.description:
TechCrunch All Stage 2025 is almost here — In 2 days, the doors swing open at Boston’s SoWa Power Station. If you’re a founder or investor, this is your last shot to lock in the lowest ticket prices before they vanish at the door.

This isn’t your average startup conference. TC All Stage is where high-growth startups get sharper, faster, and more fundable — in just one day. Whether you’re pre-seed or preparing for an IPO, this is the room to be in.

Savings of up to $475 are here until the event kicks off on July 15 at 7:30 a.m. ET, so don’t wait to grab yours at the lowest rate. Register now.

Cut through the noise, get to what matters

Forget the fluff. TC All Stage delivers hard-hitting content and real-world tactics from the experts who’ve built and backed market-moving companies.

  • Breakout sessions on raising capital, scaling operations, and building standout teams
  • Roundtable discussions that answer the questions no one else will
  • Live VC feedback and pitches from emerging startups during our “So You Think You Can Pitch” competition
  • Braindate-powered 1:1 and small-group networking to meet founders, funders, and future hires that’ll push the needle
  • After-hours Side Events across Boston to keep the conversations flowing

Get insights from the operators and investors shaping what’s next

We’re stacking the stage with big names and bold ideas. Some of the TC All Stage speakers you’ll hear in 2 days:

  • Jon McNeill, DVx Ventures (former Tesla president & Lyft COO) — How to scale sustainably
  • Tiffany Luck, NEA — How to craft the perfect pitch with strategy and storytelling.
  • Mo Jomaa, CapitalG — Planning for IPO readiness from day one.
  • Ellen Chisa, Boldstart Ventures — Building from inception with conviction.
  • Alysaa Co, Baine Capital Ventures — How early-stage teams can avoid fundraising mistakes
  • Jeff Chow, Miro — Using product-led innovation to drive team intelligence

Time is tight. So are the prices.

Right now, Founder Passes are just $100 and Investor Passes are $200 — the lowest they’ll go. In 48 hours, prices jump. Grab your pass today and be in the room where the next big deals, products, and partnerships take shape.

Register here — TechCrunch All Stage kicks off on July 15 at 7:30 a.m. ET in Boston.

Techcrunch event

Boston, MA | July 15

item.title: [NEW] Elon Musk’s SpaceX might invest $2 billion in Musk’s xAI (AI News & Artificial Intelligence | TechCrunch)
item.description:
One Elon Musk business might be making a big investment in another.

According to a Wall Street Journal report that cites investors close to SpaceX, the company has agreed to invest $2 billion in Musk’s AI startup xAI. The investment would reportedly be part of the $5 billion equity raise (along with another $5 billion in debt) that Morgan Stanley announced at the end of June.

This would be SpaceX’s first investment in xAI, and one of its biggest investments in another company. The WSJ says SpaceX already uses xAI’s chatbot Grok to power customer service for its Starlink internet service, with plans for more partnerships.

Musk has not been shy about using his various companies to support each other, for example merging xAI with X (formerly Twitter) earlier this year. And despite xAI’s recent apology for Grok’s antisemitic comments (including posts where the chatbot described itself as “MechaHitler”), Tesla is bringing Grok to its vehicles.
item.content:encoded:
One Elon Musk business might be making a big investment in another.

According to a Wall Street Journal report that cites investors close to SpaceX, the company has agreed to invest $2 billion in Musk’s AI startup xAI. The investment would reportedly be part of the $5 billion equity raise (along with another $5 billion in debt) that Morgan Stanley announced at the end of June.

This would be SpaceX’s first investment in xAI, and one of its biggest investments in another company. The WSJ says SpaceX already uses xAI’s chatbot Grok to power customer service for its Starlink internet service, with plans for more partnerships.

Musk has not been shy about using his various companies to support each other, for example merging xAI with X (formerly Twitter) earlier this year. And despite xAI’s recent apology for Grok’s antisemitic comments (including posts where the chatbot described itself as “MechaHitler”), Tesla is bringing Grok to its vehicles.
